Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Integrating nanoparticle design and in vivo testing to proactively reduce environmental impacts
PI: Tanguay, Robert L. and Hutchison, James E.
Institution: Oregon State University and the University of Oregon

There has been progress in recent years in developing basic design principles for safer nanoparticles (NPs). Although we now understand that material composition plays an important role in governing the toxicity of some materials, there is increased awareness that surface properties are particularly important when considering biocompatibility. It remains unclear how the identity of the functional groups and ligand density influence toxicity. This project will systematically explore the role of adjusting the composition, diversity and density of ligand shells in governing biocompatibility. The impact of the proposed work will be many fold. First, the products of the research will enable researchers to employ the discovered guidelines for molecular-level design as a foundation to advance materials design. The precision libraries will serve as new reference materials for the nanoEHS research community, thereby leveraging the activities of basic and applied researchers across disciplines. Society will benefit from the reduction in negative consequences of future products on health and the environment. Finally, the research team will use the integrated nature of this project to provide undergraduate and graduate students with a dynamic multidisciplinary educational experience. The co-PIs and students will communicate not only with colleagues, but also with members of the broader public. The latter goal will be achieved via hands-on and online demonstrations targeting K-12 audiences.

The PIs will develop precision engineered NP libraries that are designed specifically to define the importance of the NP surface on biocompatibility. To improve the relevance and sensitivity of biocompatibility measures, they will use the high throughput multi-dimensional embryonic zebrafish system. Determining the relationship between avidity and toxicity will inform the use of the mixtures of ligands likely to appear in next generation applications.

NSF Award # 1512755

Title: Integrating nanoparticle design and in vivo testing to proactively reduce environmental impacts

PI: Tanguay, Robert L. and Hutchison, James E.

Institution: Oregon State University and the University of Oregon

While nanotechnology has tremendous potential to address critical societal needs inventors and the public have concerns that the nanoparticles in consumer products may cause harm to humans or the environment. The number of new nano containing products being generated is outpacing efforts to understand the potential negative impacts of these materials. To advance our understanding and keep pace with innovations, we developed a collaborative team of scientists to intentionally design, synthesize and optimize the properties of nanoparticles with perfectly defined shapes to help us understand what nanoparticle structures are safe. After we synthesized these nanoparticles, we used robotic systems to study the biocompatibility of individual materials in developing zebrafish. Zebrafish and automation provides a fast, inexpensive way to screen a large number of nanoparticles, We selected zebrafish as an alternate system for humans because seventy-one percent of human proteins have an obvious orthologue in zebrafish, as do eighty-two percent of human proteins that can cause disease. Therefore, if a nanoparticle is active in zebrafish, the probability is ~70% that it will also be active in humans. Zebrafish are the most powerful, most cost-effective model for discovering the basic interactions between nanoparticles and biological systems. By combining our expertise in nanomaterial design and zebrafish screening, we successfully discovered fundamental rules that will help others produce safer materials. For example, we determined that for spherical nanomaterial that the larger nanomaterial are more toxic than smaller ones. We also determined that the surface of nanomaterial are very important in governing if a material is safe or not. When the surface of a spherical material is uniform, material is generally safer, and when nanomaterial surface defects are present, the same material is generally more toxic. These results suggest that the use of strongly bound chemicals that completely cover the surface can be used to produce safer materials. As another outcome, we challenged the common practice where nanoparticle safety is usually determined using solutions of individual particles that are free of other additives. In reality, most nano-consumer products consist of nanoparticles in combination with other materials so it is possible that the nanomaterials will interact with these additives in a mixture. In many consumer products, nanoparticles are commonly combined with surfactants (soap-like chemicals) or other additives improve a product. We studied the influence of surfactants on nanoparticle safety in embryonic zebrafish. We found that when safe surfactants and safe nanomaterial are combined, the mixtures becomes very toxic. We determined that the surfactant modified the surface of the nanomaterial, which explained the increased toxicity. These results demonstrate a need for additional studies to understand the effects of surfactants on nanoparticle safety. Overall, this project was instrumental in training several graduate students; produce several manuscripts and over a dozen public presentations.
